data.title: 17 Prince Songs You Ainâ€™t Never Heard â€” But Should (Part 1 of 2)
data.meta_description: I recently purchased a copy of Princeâ€™s Originals album from Target. The woman ringing up my and my friendâ€™s order â€” named Susan and a few years older than me â€” noticed the CD as she put it in theâ€¦
data.text:
I recently purchased a copy of Princeâ€™s Originals album from Target. The woman ringing up my and my friendâ€™s order â€” named Susan and a few years older than me â€” noticed the CD as she put it in the bag. She asked, â€œWhoâ€™s the Prince fan?â€ I confessed that both my friend and I were, but I had a more extended history with him. â€œWhatâ€™s your favorite song,â€ she asked. I jokingly said that it was a terrible question to ask a Prince fan because it was forty years of music. I finally told her, â€œProbably his first bigger hit, â€˜I Wanna Be Your Lover.â€™â€ I noticed a vague look glaze over Susanâ€™s face. I wagered Susan had not heard that song or didnâ€™t readily remember it by the title alone. After ringing a couple of more items, she said, â€œI love â€˜When Doves Cry.â€™â€ Of course, you do, Susan. â€œOh sure, that one is always a classic.â€ She was pretty proud of herself for naming â€œWhen Doves Cry.â€ It was the popular choice; a safe choice. I did my best not to roll my eyes, at least to her face. (I did in the car.) She didnâ€™t know any better.

â€œWhatâ€˜s your favorite song?â€ is always sure to weed out the posers from the pontiffs of the legacy. Itâ€™s a litmus test with Prince fans and those claiming to be Prince fans. Posers are almost always going to answer with â€œWhen Doves Cry,â€ â€œKiss,â€ â€œ1999,â€ â€œLittle Red Corvette,â€ â€œRaspberry Beret,â€ and, depending on their age, â€œDarling Nikki.â€ â€œErotic Cityâ€ is a wild card, but far from a longshot. The pontiffs will name â€œThe Ballad of Dorothy Parker,â€ or â€œElephants and Flowers,â€ likely â€œAnna Stesia.â€

So these songs might not be in the publicâ€™s eye â€” the top 40 listeners as it were, but Prince fans know them. Some may even balk at the list, â€œOh well, of course, that song, Ernest. Duh!â€ I would argue the Susan-type fans have likely missed these gems. I find them to be among the essentials for anyone wanting to learn more about Princeâ€™s music and to hear something new.

Itâ€™s no exaggeration to say Iâ€™ve been working on this list for over a year. It was initially published in an inferior form shortly after his sudden passing in 2016. With Princeâ€™s 61st birthday passing in 2019, it felt right to refresh it and make it something viable for everyone. My goal was to incorporate diversity in types of songs, bounce between album versions, b-sides, and even unreleased bootlegs circulating while making a purposeful sweep from the first album to the last before he died. Given those broad parameters, every Prince fan out there could come up with their list, and it would be entirely different than the other. Thatâ€™s the eternal beauty of Princeâ€™s music. It covers so many genres, moods, styles, narratives, production, and nuances that it becomes virtually impossible to compose the ultimate list of Prince starter songs.

With that said, this is mine.

â€œShockadelicaâ€ â€” B-side of â€œIf I Was Your Girlfriendâ€ from Sign â€˜Oâ€™ The Times, 1987

â€œIs this just a mirage U feel?â€

Former guitarist for The Time, Jesse Johnson was due to release his sophomore album, Shockadelica, sometime in 1986. Both Jesse and Prince grew up listening to groups like Parliament and Funkadelic, who invented their syntax and idioms: Psychoalphadiscobetabioaquadoloop, Funkentelechy, Gloryhallastoopid, Trombipulation, & Supergroovalisticprosifunkstication being a few. So itâ€™s no surprise that Johnson found the same inspiration to create new words. Prince would later come up with idioms in songs like â€Poom Poom,â€ â€œSuperfunkycalifragisexy,â€ and the word â€œHundalasiliah.â€

When Prince caught wind that Johnson didnâ€™t have a title track to his upcoming album, Mr. Paisley Park suggested needing a song for a title so interesting and unique. It seems odd that Johnson gave no real explanation of the title within the contents of his album. He did state in interviews that it was a word he used when he was excited about a song or a woman. Without that tidbit, itâ€™s as if the title was there just for the sake of it. That Johnson had no planned title track, Prince saw Johnsonâ€™s crime first hand. He sought to bring justice to Johnsonâ€™s seemingly blind eye. Weâ€™re not sure if Johnson thought about Princeâ€™s advice and considered writing a title track. But before he could, Prince sent a cassette of a newly finished song to Johnson. Days after it was recorded, Prince also sent it to local radio station KMOJ. The station played on air. It was a bit of a prank on Princeâ€™s part, but not everyone was laughing.

Jesse refused to use the song. While immensely talented, Jesse has always been the tortured soul of The Time. It stands to argue that the second track on the album, â€œCrazay,â€ (a song featuring funk legend Sly Stone) seems a more appropriate statement for not taking a great Prince song for his album. When KMOJ played the song, the word of the prank made its way around music news outlets, including MTV News. Once Johnsonâ€™s album came out weeks later, it appeared that Johnson had lifted Princeâ€™s song title for his album. Prince punked Jesse in his home town in a very public way. While Prince saw it as all in good fun, Johnson didnâ€™t find the joke funny. Jesse was already well aware that he would forever be under the umbrella of his buddy and former employer. He worked hard to establish himself as a solo artist fully independent of anything Prince-related. So Prince temporarily putting the song out, even on local radio, undoubtedly irritated Jesse and stole some thunder. Prince said in a statement he had no plans to release the track.

Plot twist: Prince did release the song the following year (well after the release of Johnsonâ€™s album). It backed the second single from Sign â€˜Oâ€™ The Times, â€œIf I Was Your Girlfriend.â€ To the home crowd, the joke had been made. Prince: 1, Jesse: 0. To the public that didnâ€™t know about the joke, it would seem Prince recorded a song based on Jesseâ€™s album title after the fact. But, MTV News kept the timeline straight, as did Princeâ€™s fanbase.

The song is a steam warehouse, assembly line, funk workout that details the narratorâ€™s story of a dangerously loose woman who seduces men with her body and makes them do things they wouldnâ€™t normally do. He compares her to a citizen of Paradise Island, aka Themyscira.

She got U tied with a golden rope

She wonâ€™t let U play your guitar

And when Uâ€™ve cried enough

Maybe sheâ€™ll let U up

His conversation about her feels grimy but danceable, presenting an indulgence few would consume. It wouldnâ€™t be unusual for one to feel dread by the time the song ends. The whole song reeks of a sexually-dystopian torture factory. Through the scene with her, he attempts to overcome her influence, yelling at her to â€œget up, you be lyinâ€™ on my guitar, nasty bitch, get up!â€ Itâ€™s another example of Prince putting himself in submission to a woman in his music. Rarely is he the sexual aggressor. The song flags as a warning for listeners to heed his advice, yet he seems perfectly willing to put himself in the same position.

His warning is parallel to a biblical parable which tells a story of a certain rich man who ignored others in place of his selfish desires. When he dies, he goes to hell and is tortured. He begs for pity from Abraham, asking him to tell his family about hell so they wonâ€™t suffer his demise. Abraham says theyâ€™ve already had their warning; if they ignore it, itâ€™s their fault. Princeâ€™s downfall seems to be the forewarning for anyone tempted by Shockadelica.

With this woman, men (or possibly other women) lose all cognitive ability to make decisions to save themselves; she seems to intoxicate them.

Shockadelica â€” She got U in a trance

Cuz when this woman say dance, U dance

Shockadelica â€” U need a second opinion, but U just canâ€™t leave her alone

With her U got no mind of your own

Itâ€™s also a scene we hear in â€œAutomaticâ€ (1999, 1982), where the women torture him showing no mercy. Whereas Prince commonly uses sex and spirituality as the same, here, sex is used as a punishment for oneâ€™s carnal desires.

Shockadelica is a feeling, the lonely cold

Sleepinâ€™ alone will bore ya and.. and soon U grow old

In lust we will suffer, but in love we will grow

Shockadelica is a feeling nobody should know

Itâ€™s possible Prince is using the character of Shockadelica as a metaphor for loneliness. He explores many aspects of loneliness in his music (some of which I cover in my Batman 30 article). Here is no different, warning that being in a perpetual and long-term state of loneliness can drive a person to unusual acts and possibly insanity. He sets the scene of going to bed by oneâ€™s self and the emotions â€” or possible hallucinations â€” that extended solitude can bring.

The lights go out, the smell of doom

Is creepinâ€™ into your lonely room

The bedâ€™s on fire, your fate is sealed

And Uâ€™re so tired and the reason is Camille

Camille was a character created by Prince around this time who initially succumbs to evil, but is eventually redeemed by good. (â€œShockadelicaâ€ was also due to be part of an album called Camille which all employed the same sped-up vocal technique.) Prince never resolves how to stop the woman from doing what sheâ€™s doing (or to put clothes on, because â€œshe never wears a stitch, you canâ€™t take her homeâ€). The last word you hear him say is her name, with some ethereal echo behind his voice, almost as if he was sucked back into her world of seduction and manipulation, or heâ€™s dying. She is the last thing on his mind. If the metaphor is true, then heâ€™s dying, still in solitude. Excessive solitude and loss of self are explored in â€œSoloâ€ (Come, 1993).

Iâ€™m so lost, no one can find me

And Iâ€™ve been looking 4 so long

But now Iâ€™m done

The original full-length version of â€œShockadelicaâ€ was released as the â€œextended version,â€ whereas the edit is included on the 7" single and The Hits/The B-Sides. The extended versions of his songs were often the original versions. The song was quoted on The Purple Medley EP track, â€œKirky Jâ€™s B-Sides Remix.â€

2. â€œBabyâ€ â€” For You, 1978

â€œI barely have enough money for twoâ€

Princeâ€™s debut record had a few lowkey trinkets, but nothing as chart breaking as his eponymous sophomore albumâ€™s â€œI Wanna Be Your Loverâ€ the following year. For You was quietly noticed by critics when it was released. And while there was a buzz around this prodigy from Minneapolis, his debut felt underwhelming; yet the talent couldnâ€™t be denied. I say underwhelming in the best way possible, as his only trajectory was up.

There are treasures on the record, and itâ€™s worth exploring. Itâ€™s not the usual in-your-face funk acrobatics, later labeled as the Minneapolis sound that weâ€™d come to know Prince for over time. Itâ€™s a soft and radio-friendly yacht-rock quasi-funk worthy deluge of an R&B and pop hybrid. One wonders if he would have enjoyed any semblance of known success had he continued to make the type of music on For You or Prince. Thank heavens he didnâ€™t.

Tucked into the middle of For You, â€œBaby,â€ is a questioning song about getting his girlfriend pregnant before either of them planned on it, layered with lush vocal feats doing their flips above then-lavish production. He questions whether they can support a child since he has no money (a statement he declared later in â€œI Wanna Be Your Lover,â€ â€œI ainâ€™t got no moneyâ€), but also expresses no regrets in finding out he accidentally got her pregnant. He is still firmly a teenager, thinking they were above nature and science, â€œI never would have thought that this would happen/2 a very careful man like meâ€.

Whether he was political or not (likely, he wasnâ€™t), the song is a pro-choice stance on single motherhood, giving her the choice what to do and heâ€™ll be supportive of her decision.

Should we go on living 2gether?

Should we get married right away?

Whatever U decide, Iâ€™ll still love U baby

And weâ€™ll grow stronger every day

It acts as a precursor to Madonnaâ€™s â€œPapa Donâ€™t Preach,â€ expressing the same â€œyeah, butâ€ when learning sheâ€™s with a child. Madonna pleads with her father not to expel her from the family home, saying sheâ€™s keeping her baby, extolling her babyâ€™s fatherâ€™s marriage proposal and a seemingly new life ahead.

He says that heâ€™s going to marry me

We can raise a little family

Maybe weâ€™ll be all right

Itâ€™s a sacrifice

Prince seems to have taken a similar role promising to find a way to build a family with the mother of his child instead of ejecting himself from the situation. Itâ€™s equally pro-life and pro-choice and a much more positive spin on unwed mothers in the 70s. (Madonnaâ€™s song and its existence balked at an 80s Reagan-era conservative headset.) Prince takes his responsibility for their sexual hiccup but equally questions their future, as she does.

Baby, what are we gonna do?

I barely have enough money 4 2

Baby, what are we gonna do?

I donâ€™t want 2 regret what Iâ€™ve done 2 U

For a teenager, itâ€™s very forward thinking. Then again, when one is a teenager, anything seems logical and perfectly viable; it almost seems easy. Thereâ€™s no doubt that it stems from the dynamics in Princeâ€™s own family and his father leaving when he was a very young child. The familial thread would weave itself through the fabric of Princeâ€™s music throughout his entire career.

It stands to note that Prince would upcycle the lush-factor of this song seventeen years later. â€œBabyâ€â€™s instrumental accent break at the 1:12 mark â€” and the only time it happens in the song â€” would be used as the main hook for â€œğŸ‘ Hate U,â€ from The Gold Experience. His glistening vocals and swirling orchestration surround the break in this song, and remains relatively unchanged on The Gold Experience, albeit replayed with newer instruments and production value. His tender falsetto offers an air of fragility and unsureness to the songâ€™s content, conveying a one-step-a-time approach to solving their problem. â€œBabyâ€ is a tender song about a tough choice young adults face every day. It makes one wonder if it werenâ€™t written from a real experience Prince had with a girl.

PS They had a boy.

3. â€œLoveleft, Loverightâ€ â€” B-side of New Power Generation EP from Graffiti Bridge, 1990

â€œLike the way my booty goesâ€

When asked who he likes on the radio, Prince used to say that if he wanted new music, heâ€™d make it himself. The whole EP of New Power Generation, a track to officially coin and memorialize the name of his band and eventual record company stamp, is the genesis of that idea. The EP shows Princeâ€™s still-burgeoning genius with taking his music and making something new from it.

While he chose a fill from â€œBabyâ€ for â€œğŸ‘ Hate U,â€ the New Power Generation EP stands as one of the first examples of going beyond the usual remix or extended mix fare into a whole new orgy of aural orgasms. He would revisit the idea with the EPs for â€œCreamâ€ and â€œGett Off,â€ (both songs from 1991â€™s Diamonds and Pearls album), having their grab bags of reworked trinkets. He had already dipped his tootsies in the overly-extended-mix pool when he took the under-3-minute trotting â€œI Wish U Heavenâ€ (Lovesexy, 1988) into a â€œ10:somethingâ€ musical extravaganza jam with three distinct music sections (a portion of which was another song called â€œTake This Beatâ€). The Batman track â€œScandalousâ€ was turned into 19+ minutes, three-section suite of guitar solos, seductive dialog, and Kim Basingerâ€™s orgasmic moans that would give Donna Summerâ€™s â€œLove To Love You Babyâ€ a run for its money. (By the way, Summerâ€™s hit clocks at 16:49, and The Scandalous Sex Suite rings in at 19:15; which I guess means Prince can last longer.)

The last three tracks on New Power Generation EP are almost an EP unto themselves. â€œGet Offâ€ (not to be confused with the Diamonds and Pearls track), â€œThe Lubricated Ladyâ€ (which is more connected to â€œGet Offâ€ than its own track), & â€œLoveleft, Loverightâ€ run into each other to happily drag the listener through sex, braggadocio and a menage a trois. However, itâ€™s â€œLoveleft, Loverightâ€ that is the highlight of the three. With Prince noodling around on his guitar, and a chant of â€œParty 2night â€” oh yeah!â€ throughout, how can one not dance to this? The songâ€™s modulation and its inclusion of a choir disguise it as a gospel song. It joyfully meshes the idea of a sexual threeway with spiritual bliss. Itâ€™s a theme Prince has explored in his career â€” sex and salvation cumming together as one.

The genius of this EP is that Prince took elements or musical ideas from â€œNew Power Generationâ€ and used them as the structure for new songs. It feels more experimental, whereas Gett Off EP and Cream EP feel like more fleshed out ideas; namely the former with its full onslaught of hashed-out songs, but Cream EP has shorter takes on music ideologies from its original mothersong.

â€œLoveleft, Loverightâ€ puts the final glorious period on the whole shindig of freedom, sex, and joy. Prince flags his repetitive idea of a new world and freedom, not only heard in â€œNew Power Generationâ€ but earlier songs like â€œUptownâ€ and â€œSexualityâ€ and inserts himself (quite literally or figuratively) as a leader of a new sexual revolution. Heâ€™s starting it with a bang, or two. Or three.

The faux-gospel track is a simple street corner cat calling to random women walking by, using other women has his selling point. He figures if other women have had him, why wouldnâ€™t the next couple of women that walk by him?

The Girls of Soul

Like the way my booty goes

They say the curves deserve another glance (Curves deserve)

Come on, pretty baby, give me a chance

2 prove my brotherhood

Iâ€™ll make it real good

Iâ€™ll do ya, Iâ€™ll do ya, Iâ€™ll do ya like U wanna should

It seems almost humorous, possibly on purpose, that Prince would try to pick up two women at once. But are the two women having it or not? We donâ€™t know their freak number, but we know Princeâ€™s in this song.

I canâ€™t help it, baby (Love 2 the left of me)

It really gets me gone

2 think about the 3 of us g-goinâ€™ on

It harkens to the â€œWhispering Playa Interludeâ€ on TLCâ€™s Fanmail album (before â€œNo Scrubsâ€), where a guy is trying to approach T-Boz and Chili for a sexual encounter.

Yaâ€™ll rollinâ€™ together. Ya know what Iâ€™m sayinâ€™. Well, we can just bounce to my crib, ya know what Iâ€™m sayin? (whispering) Do that menage a trois.

Being Prince, he probably landed both chicks.

Listening note: At the end of â€œThe Lubricated Lady,â€ â€” just before â€œLoveleft, Loverightâ€ begins â€” you can hear the tape run out, its tail flapping against the tape machine, as he asks his engineer, â€œeverything alright back there?â€

Indeed it is, Prince. Indeed it is.

4. â€œViolet The Organ Grinderâ€ â€” B-side of Gett Off EP from Diamonds & Pearls, 1991

â€œI can deal with a sucker if heâ€™s in your mouthâ€

Prince once again shreds â€œGett Offâ€ â€” the lead single from 1991â€²s Diamonds & Pearls â€” into a host of tracks, which cover instrumentals, house styled music and downright nasty grinds that would make even darling Nikki blush. He followed his guide from New Power Generation EP and put out a half-dozen tracks on the Gett Off EP. The first couple of the tracks are proper remixes, but the songs vary more with â€œViolet The Organ Grinder,â€ which feels like a cousin to â€œGett Off,â€ albeit a cousin by marriage.

Violet, the narrator, laments being relegated as a sexual toy for women. He seems to wrestle with the tropes of love and connection while being a sex worker, an often disconnected sexual job. He falls to his default position of being an instrument for anotherâ€™s pleasure rather than having some peace (or piece) of his own. He takes himself out of his doldrums by bragging and taunting the women he serviced with their gifts to him and how he used them on his own time to still pleasure himself thinking of pleasuring them. Itâ€™s cyclical self-torture. Itâ€™s a subservient stance he, again, places himself in with women. They use him, but even when theyâ€™re gone, heâ€™s mesmerized by their memory, their smell, and their money. He seems to be stuck in a consistent loop of being a willing victim, instead of the perpetrator. Although, who is making who do what here?

I live 4 the organ that I am grinding

Iâ€™ll die, but I wonâ€™t go away

Itâ€™s a mournful pity-party, yet the hook of the song feels more infectious and alive than â€œGett Offâ€ itself; although â€œGett Offâ€ certainly has its bags of male vibrato throughout.

The song also contains the most clever lyrics for that period and a favorite for me.

â€œI do believe my piano was stolen

I do believe that U want me near

Well I can deal with a sucker if heâ€™s in your mouth

But I canâ€™t deal with insincereâ€

Even amid the acceptance of his allotment in life, he still yearns for something real, a connection, with his clients or with anyone who can understand him. Itâ€™s a theme explored before in The Timeâ€™s â€œGigolos Get Lonely Too,â€ with Morris Day lamenting a similar position.

Just once I wanna make love without takinâ€™ off my clothes

Just once I wanna make love with somebody who knows

That I got more money than U could ever see

But honey, money wonâ€™t get me up off my knees

Maybe this is Princeâ€™s version of sexual purgatory, a place of in-between, muddling around with familiarity yet unknown things to come in oneâ€™s afterlife before landing in their last home.

The whole of the Gett Off EP is an amazing listen, ending with the coupled â€œGangsta Glamâ€ and â€œClockinâ€™ the Jizzâ€ rounding out the set.

5. â€œGroovy Potentialâ€ â€” HITnRUN Phase Two, 2015

For those who know me and my stance on Prince music, theyâ€™ll usually find me innately happy with just about anything Prince releases. Some things grow on one faster than others, but ultimately itâ€™s always a joy to hear Prince music, old and new. Theyâ€™ll also find me to be painfully honest when Prince released something that I thought was below his purple standard of excellence. I am not a fan who wants Prince to stay in the 80s for his career. The mid-90s is one of my favorite eras with stellar projects like Exodus, Come, The Gold Experience, the BEAUTIFUL experience, Love Symbol, and Chaos and Disorder. It was in the early aughts that Princeâ€™s aural aesthetic started to change. It flattened, became compressed. Gone were reverbed vocals or echoey drums, or wet and dirty guitar filters. Someone described it as acrylic, which seemed to sum it up perfectly. It was too perfect, transparent, clean, dry, smooth edges, nothing to rip you to shreds any more. When you listen to Prince music, you want to get knocked in the teeth, punched in the throat, slapped like a bitch. Once Prince got into his 40s, he became G-rated or PG-rated at the most. He was suddenly lyrically safe, not as daring anymore. Sure, there are lovely songs, catchy hooks, and the mostly-sing-along chorus here and there. Compared to any other era of Princeâ€™s music, the aughts and onward became a gamble of what to bet on, what to stay on, and knowing when to fold. At most youâ€™d get a slight blister from its smooth edges rubbing on you too long. Nothing was setting your hair on fire anymore.

Prince would pepper the internet with singles and his newer sound throughout the 2000s, sometimes going as long as four years between full-fledged records. It was a normal state of affairs for people like Michael Jackson, who could take time to rest on that Bad or Dangerous money and live a little. But for a prolific writer like Prince â€” who typically released one album a year â€” it seemed like world war III came and we missed it. Prince just stopped making music for the public. Fans would argue he had long stopped making music to be a hit; he did it because â€œthatâ€™s just what he did.â€ If he just wanted to release music for the sake of it, heâ€™d not have charged for it, did interviews, or serviced it to radio stations.

But in 2013, on his then-active 3rdEyeTunes website, he released â€œGroovy Potential.â€ While some of the songs released in recent years were more desirable than others (including his 20Ten album which I enjoyed), it was â€œGroovy Potentialâ€ that gave me a glimmer of hope about Princeâ€™s musical direction. There was something melodic and groovy about the song. It slowly comes into itself. A ten-piece horn section subtly punctuating Princeâ€™s almost-reverbed-live vocals and his smooth adult-jazz guitar strumming chords that feel like warm caramel are all ingredients that take this mid-tempo track into an easy-going jam. Prince backs off from too many choruses or verses and often lets the song ruminate on its own. At the right times, he thunders back, making his case to be the right lover for the woman heâ€™s trying to seduce into a relationship. Youâ€™d almost expect the song to end just short of five minutes into the track, yet he quiets the path back to its finger snaps and smooth synth chords, keeping a gentle groove underneath an otherwise quiet storm. Then in the last 30-seconds brings it back up to a funky stomp that could only be fully realized in a pair of Cuban-heeled boots.

The song was released on the 2016 HITnRUN Phase Two CD, his last album just months before his passing that year. The album streamed on Tidal and was available on iTunes in December 2015, but Iâ€™m listing it as 2016, the physical release date.

6. â€œIn A Large Room With No Lightâ€ â€” original unreleased, but circulating; new version 2009

â€œif U could just pass your history classâ€

A much sought after track, from May 1986, that has been bootlegged in horrible quality. For years, no one what the hell to call it. Whenever it showed up on a bootleg set, it was often labeled as â€œWelcome to the Rat Race,â€ or rarely â€œLife Is Like Looking For A Penny In A Large Room With No Light.â€ Years later on one of his many sites, Prince confirmed it was â€œIn A Large Room with No Light.â€ The song was originally due to be part of the Dream Factory project and credited to Prince & the Revolution. It was later removed from the configuration. The whole project was shelved.

The track has machine-gunned lyrics, with a manic drum track, and puts its jazz influences right up front. Itâ€™s easy to see why The Revolution was credited on this track. While Prince could have recorded this on his own (and perhaps did at some point), it was much more engaging as a Prince song with the support of a live band. The Revolution was arguably Princeâ€™s best configuration of his band in the 80s. Members of Sheila E.â€™s band also played on the track. The song was never part of any released project, which was disappointing. The controlled freneticism in the song appeals to the most loyal of Prince listeners, and would undoubtedly rub any other music fan the same way; with an appreciation of controlled syncopation, intertwined melodic components, complex rhythms, and a melody that is quite comfortable resting on its eighth and sixteenth notes. Its lyrics speak to sadder situations of life and the mediocrity that keeps many people trapped in a cycle of despair and neglect, either of themselves or those around them.

â€œLana drew a picture in school 2day

One that made her mother cry

A picture of a woman with a drink in her hand

Standing by a child with no eyesâ€

It laments the spoon-fed misery of snake oil salesmen and those who are ignorant enough to buy it. He would also visit an ongoing concern of war and killing innocent people.

Washington reaction based upon revenge

Babies blown 2 kingdom come

Damn the logic

Cartoon characters look better when theyâ€™re on the run

He would talk later about war â€œSign â€˜Oâ€™ The Times,â€ â€œDance On,â€ â€œMoonbeam Levels,â€ â€œUptown,â€ and more. One has to remember that the 80s were a period in history when the Cold War was in full effect. Russia and the United States werenâ€™t friendly, Cuba was under communist rule, and children were still learning nuclear bomb emergency drills in school. It wasnâ€™t some abstract thought; it was a real threat. Although heâ€™s technically a baby boomer, born in 1958, he came up and was raised with us Generation X types. It was a unique position for artists like him, Madonna, and Michael Jackson to be in as they formed their craft, able to express their fears through music.

The song steps away from social commentary near the end to let the musicians show their talent. The song highlights the fact that Prince was more than just an R&B singer or a funk musician. There are hours and days of instrumental music Prince recorded as far back as 1985 onward. This is one of those, albeit, with lyrics, that shows off his jazz leanings and prowess.

Prince would later re-record the song in 2009, removing a verse with a cuss word in it. Ironically, the verse he removed was the one that caused early confusion the songâ€™s title.

â€œEvery time U wake up thereâ€™s a little motherfucker

Talkinâ€™ big stuff in your face (Are U happy?)

U only get the kind of people that open their mouth just 2 swap feet

Welcome 2 the rat raceâ€

A UK radio station premiered the updated version and was streamed on the Montreaux Jazz Festival site. It was noted that the song had been completed only two days before being aired. It coincided with his headlining appearance that year at the festival. Itâ€™s not been released since 2009 on any streaming platform, which is surprising as most of his available published catalog was almost immediately put on Spotify, Prime Music, iTunes, and more.

7. â€œJoy In Repetitionâ€ â€” Graffiti Bridge, 1990

â€œHe lost himself in the articulated mannerâ€

Dating back to 1986, â€œJoy In Repetitionâ€ finally saw the light of day on Graffiti Bridge, the soundtrack of the quasi-sequel to Purple Rain. Prince was riding a successful train with having released the #1 soundtrack to Batman the year prior. He found new life in movies; a medium he had long desired to be part of after the success of Purple Rain (1984), then the failure of Under The Cherry Moon (1986), later the success of Sign â€˜Oâ€™ The Times (1987). The movie bombed, but the album was full of Prince treasures; many tracks dating from the mid-80s and often slightly updated. The song was completed the day before the unreleased, but legendary Dream Factory was initially compiled. The song wasnâ€™t included in the tracklist. However, it was included in the Crystal Ball project, which was a later extension of the Dream Factory project. â€œğŸ‘ Noâ€ was still in its early form as â€œThe Ball,â€ and â€œJoy In Repetitionâ€ was sequenced after â€œThe Ball,â€ including the familiar crowd noise. The crowd noise heard at the beginning of â€œJoy In Repetitionâ€ can also be heard at the end of â€œğŸ‘ Noâ€ on Lovesexy, and is used to segue into â€œAlphabet St.â€ Like â€œ17 Daysâ€, â€œJoy In Repetitionâ€ seemed to be a song in search of an album. While Iâ€™m not sure if Graffiti Bridge does the songâ€™s existence justice, it certainly gave fans an official release of the track.

â€œJoy In Repetitionâ€ is a speak-sing song, where the narrator talks about seeing a girl performing at a club. It was open mic-night, and she kept saying two words over and over, yearning for a connection with anyone. He is so enthralled with this female that he snags her and pulls her out the back door of the club. Sheâ€™s lost in her daze of desire and continues to repeatâ€¦

These 2 words â€” a little bit behind the beat

I mean just enough 2 turn U on

4 every time she said the words

Another one of his doubts were gone

When they get together, thereâ€™s so much passion between them â€” her obsession with a mate and him intoxicated by her dual-syllabic poetry â€” that the only words she can speak are â€œLove me.â€ The song is noted for its laid-back bluesy approach, with a sultry guitar solo that travels throughout the latter half. The soaring â€œJOY!â€ background vocals are again reminiscent of a religious or gospel tone on a song thatâ€™s about nothing much more than seduction and sex. However, itâ€™s not to be dismissed as just another song about Prince trying to nail a woman in a back alley. The lyrics to this song are poetry unto themselves and uses words one doesnâ€™t usually use for a song (much like the first time I heard Terence Trent Dâ€™Arbyâ€ use unusual verbiage of â€œsupermodel sandwich with cheeseâ€ on Vibrator).

â€œUp on the mic repeating 2 words over and over again

Was this woman he had never noticed before

He lost himself in the articulated manner in which she said themâ€

By the time Prince gets the girl alone with him, he takes a moment to catch his breath, then launches into a fantastic guitar solo that can only be thought of as the six-string representation of intercourse and orgasm.

The song drips with sensuality, and sex, and shows how much of an appealing yet lyrically complex song Prince can write when he sits down to do so. I wonder how it would have been received segueing from â€œThe Ball,â€ in the 80s. It feels like this would have kept Prince solidly at the front of the pack as one of the best lyric writers alive.

8. â€œBaltimoreâ€ â€” HITnRUN Phase Two, 2016

â€œEnough is enough, itâ€™s time for loveâ€

When twenty-five-year-old Freddie Gray was arrested, abused by police (his spine broken in the process), he was handcuffed and put in the back of a police van. The officers drove so aggressively as to throw Gray around in the vehicle, taking the long way to the station. He subsequently died from his injuries while in police custody. The situation didnâ€™t go unnoticed by rioters, nor by Prince. As riots raged in Baltimore, Maryland, Prince took to his studio to express his disgust and anger at the police killing a black man, again. The song also namechecks eighteen-year-old Michael Brown, another young black man shot the year prior and left to bleed out in the streets of Ferguson, Missouri while a cop, Darrin Wilson, stood over him offering no assistance, later claiming he was â€œscared for his life.â€ A streaming version of the song was made available on 3rd Eye Girlâ€™s Soundcloud account (Princeâ€™s all-girl group that completed his 4-piece band) barely a week after it was recorded. It was officially released as a digital single in late May, then was the opening track for HITnRUN Phase Two in 2016.

While hearing the synopsis of the song, one would think this would be an aggressive and angry song or a dirge reserved for emotive listening parties. Prince approaches it from an upbeat standpoint, leaning into anthemic sensibilities rather than giving into his inner turmoil to express his anger and disgust. Prince lived and revealed himself and his ideologies, beliefs, and convictions (while they lasted since they changed every few years like he rotated band members) through his music. His music was his way to riot. And his opinions about police brutality are right up front on â€œBaltimore.â€ Any Prince fan knows he can act out on a record. Whether heâ€™s charging up a crowd to party, lamenting a lost love, or falling to the wiles of a woman, Princeâ€™s music was his emotional outlet.

In â€œBaltimore,â€ his vocal delivery feels genuine, authentic. Itâ€™s hard to believe there was any pretending on this song, of any sort; he wasnâ€™t acting, he was serious. What we hear is what he was feeling right when he recorded it. If Prince worked out his demons in his music, then this one should be one of the top examples. The lyrics sit nicely on Princeâ€™s lips, uniformly delivering his version of Black Lives Matter and his seemingly blind eschewing of the second amendment.

â€œNobody got in nobodyâ€™s way

So I guess you could say it was a good day

At least a little better than the day in Baltimore

Does anybody hear us pray

For Michael Brown or Freddie Gray?

Peace is more than the absence of warâ€¦

Are we gonna see another bloody day?

Weâ€™re tired of the cryinâ€™ and people dyinâ€™

Letâ€™s take all the guns awayâ€

He had previously addressed the Hurricane Katrina flooding of New Orleans in â€œS.S.T. (Sadeâ€™s Sweetest Taboo),â€ and further back addressed AIDS, the arms race, space race, and the heightened drug war brought on by the Reagan administration in various songs. Prince was never one to shy away from challenging social constructs or political norms. He did it in ways that were constructed to capture the listenerâ€™s attention and hold it. He updates his 1981 anti-war song, â€œPartyupâ€ and its anti-war chant:

Uâ€™re gonna have 2 fight your own damn war

Cuz we donâ€™t wanna fight no more!

â€¦and brings it into the twenty-first century. â€œIf there ainâ€™t no justice/then there ainâ€™t no peace.â€

If there ainâ€™t no justice

Then thre ainâ€™t no peace!

It was with â€œBaltimoreâ€ that Prince expressed a new sound. Prince would record his guitar solo, then give the song over to a person he had asked to write orchestrations for the guitar solo, literally to rewrite the guitar solo with an orchestra. Prince would then take the two and blend them in the final mix, often crossfading from one to the other. The strings start as the â€˜solo,â€™ but it soon becomes a guitar solo. Itâ€™s a simplistic bloom of an idea that has the fragrance of something fresh and new. Frankly, Princeâ€™s music needed something new in it. The man had tried and done almost everything out there it seemed. Radio certainly needed a shot of new spunk since the Top 40 charts were (and still are to some degree) littered with GarageBand-ridden songs written by high schoolers with a MacBook Air and a lot of free time. It was reported that Prince was very excited about the idea and had expressed that he found a new sound for his music. Sadly, HITnRUN Phase Two, to our knowledge, will be the only real examples.

â€œBaltimoreâ€ served as the theme for the ensuing Rally4Peace. When the song was released digitally, the last part of the liner notes read:

â€œPlease know that all involved in this project never take for granted the privileges we have in this country. Letâ€™s all continue to fight the good fight and confront inhumanity on every level until the day it is no longer.â€

9. â€œBig Cityâ€ â€” HITnRUN Phase Two, 2016

Alright you Polaroids, letâ€™s go!

The last track for HITnRUN Phase Two is a fun, upbeat walk with his whole band in tow. It includes vocals Ledisi, and Liv Warfield, plus a mix of his 3rd Eye Girl group and New Power Generation, late-drummer John Blackwell, Ida Nelson, Elisa Dease, and Shelby J. It was streamed and played live on a few occasions a couple of years before it saw the light of day on HITnRUN Phase Two. Lyrically, it celebrates the love of a woman, and how he feels as if heâ€™s in the biggest city around when theyâ€™re together. The whole world is at his fingertips in her presence.

â€œWhere ever we are itâ€™s a big city

Dirty little hotel room or working on a farm

If everybody is a star, to me, youâ€™re the most pretty

Iâ€™m in the big cityâ€¦

When Iâ€™m in your armsâ€

Itâ€™s an upbeat and triumphant take on love. One does wonder what sort of love or relationship Prince enjoyed near the end of his life. Singer Judith Hill was near him in his last year, but we never really know if they had an intimate relationship. Of course, itâ€™s Prince. Anything is possible. But if not, perhaps it was just Prince pulling from the better part of his previous relationships. Prince often seemed as happy as he seemed sad. His gaunt experience at his final Piano and a Microphone concerts almost made fans wish he did have someone in his life to look after him and care for him; to influence him to take better care of himself.

â€œBig Cityâ€ doesnâ€™t take itself too seriously with huge statements about its merit as a Prince song. Itâ€™s driving undercurrent, large horn section, jangly saloon-inspired piano riff and group vocals feel like a jam worthy of a few encores. Shelby J.â€™s vocal icing behind Princeâ€™s lead vocal reminds one of Chaka Khan adding the same effect on Steve Winwoodâ€™s â€œHigher Love.â€ As flat as Princeâ€™s production had become in the previous twenty years or so, â€œBig Cityâ€ feels much more open and welcoming, bright and joyous. You can almost see Prince and his cohorts strutting down the French Quarter with a brass section and some percussionists in tow bringing his music to the masses.

â€œBig Cityâ€ remedies presumptuous upbeat crowd songs like â€œGet On The Boatâ€ (3121, 2006), his remake of Sheryl Crowâ€™s â€œEveryday Is A Winding Roadâ€ (with its cringe-worthy Larry Graham chant) (Rave Un2 the Joy Fantastic, 1999), or the lame attempt â€œExpress Yourselfâ€ makeover of â€œFeel Better, Feel Good, Feel Wonderfulâ€ (LotusFlow3r, 2009). HITnRUN Phase Two is one of his more cohesive albums of the twenty-first century, one that cares about what the listener is hearing. It glories in stark contrast to previous records that exhibited an insular echo chamber laced with dogmatic proclamations and historical revision (read: The Rainbow Children, The Slaughterhouse).

The song also employs the aforementioned new sound Prince had materialized on â€œBaltimore,â€ that of being an orchestrated guitar solo and some clever cross-fading. Who knows how Prince would have manipulated that idea into synth, bass, or even vocal sections of a song. The two songs that most highlight his new sound bookend HITnRUN Phase Two, and seem to offer some hope and insight into a new phase of Princeâ€™s music, and an older and wiser Prince. He was crossing over into the role of sage rather than student.

Unfortunately, the joy of â€œBig Cityâ€ is quickly squelched at its end, bringing a morbid sense of finality. HITnRUN Phase Two would be his last release while alive. He would die three months to the day after its release. Fans swarm over conspiracy theories of him planning his passing, but Prince loved life. Itâ€™s overly morbid and a romanticized filter to view a tragic and untimely death of one of the greatest artists in a generation, or three. As with most Prince factoids, it was a bit of pure serendipity. One cannot deny that, in typical Prince fashion, his last two words on tape would be the most unintentionally prophetic yet.

â€œThatâ€™s it.â€
